feed.title: Combined summary - Lightning Network's effect on miner fees

entry.title: Combined summary - Lightning Network's effect on miner fees
entry.summary: The Lightning Network is an off-chain solution for Bitcoin transactions that is ideal for smaller, predictable transactions such as utility bills, groceries, rent, and mortgage. It is economically sensible to use the Lightning Network for transactions where the fee to include the transaction on the blockchain is more than the Time Value of Money of the encumbered funds on the Lightning Nodes amortized across the number of users pushing funds through a LN node. By minimizing the set of costs/externalities to the minimum necessary to conduct a series of transactions, there will be less transactions on the mainchain, which means fewer fees collected by the miners.However, this has raised concerns about the impact of the Lightning Network on miner fees. With fewer transactions on the mainchain, there will be less collected fees for miners. When block rewards disappear, on-chain transaction fees may increase to impractical levels, leading miners to leave and potentially decreasing the network's hashing power, which is a security feature that makes some attacks impossible or expensive. As hashing power is important, it is imperative to anticipate what will happen in this scenario.Regarding the incentives of everyone involved in the lightning network, such as payment channel endpoints, hub operators, and miners, they have not been fully seen yet. It might make sense to enforce a percentage of the fees collected by payment hubs to be spent as miner fees, regardless of whether the transactions from that hub go on the main chain or not. Additionally, the author questions the impact of LN on miner fees if transactions are processed off-chain and only broadcasted on the mainchain. There is a debate about whether the Lightning Network (LN) will lower fees for on-chain transactions or not. The effect of the Lightning Network on fees is going to be hard to predict, as it depends on user behavior around the dynamics of bid-side demand of fees. New classes of transactions will be possible that aren't possible today, and the market effect of 'instant' transactions after a network-joining-intro period will have on Bitcoin's utility/price/adoption is yet to be seen.It would be useful if blockchain data scientists could study the effect of the fee market when high-volume exchanges unexpectedly halted trading. Large-value transactions that will be on the blockchain have more flexible time-settlement tolerance, and Lightning Network hot wallets are not an ideal place to store large quantities of BTC. Users that don't expect to be actively using the Lightning Network should prefer confirmed UTXOs for long-term cold storage. Overall, while LN is a complementary technology to Bitcoin, it still relies on the underlying blockchain to function. Users are advised not to store large amounts of BTC in LN hot wallets and instead opt for confirmed UTXOs for long-term cold storage.
